machine
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Compare machine, tool, etc. ÊÔ±È½Ïmachine¡¢ toolµÈ´Ê. A machine consists of moving parts powered by electricity, etc and is designed for a specific job. *machineÊÇÓÉµçÁ¦µÈÇı¶¯µÄ»úÆ÷, ÊÇÎª×öÄ³ÖÖ¹¤×÷¶øÉè¼ÆµÄ. An (electrical) appliance is a machine used in the house, such as awashing-machine or dishwasher. *(electrical) applianceÊÇ¼ÒÓÃµçÆ÷, ÈçÏ´ÒÂ»ú»òÏ´µú»ú. An apparatus is a system of connected machines, wires, etc *apparatusÊÇÏàÁª½áµÄ»úÆ÷¡¢ µ¼ÏßµÈÏµÍ³: the apparatus for lighting the stage ÎèÌ¨ÕÕÃ÷Éè±¸. A tool is an object held in the hand, often used by people in their jobs, eg a hammer, drill or spanner. *toolÊÇÊÖ³Ö¹¤¾ß, ³£Îª¸É»î¶ùµÄÈËÓÃµÄ, Èç¡¡×Ó¡¢ ×ê»ò°â×Ó. An instrument is a tool designed for a technical task, eg a surgeon's knife. *instrumentÊÇÎª¼¼Êõ¹¤×÷Éè¼ÆµÄ¹¤¾ß, ÈçÊÖÊõµ¶. It may have some moving parts and be used in a technical operation, eg a microscope or meter. *instrument¿ÉÄÜÓĞÄ³Ğ©ÔË×ª²¿¼ş²¢ÓÃì¶¼¼Êõ²Ù×÷, ÈçÏÔÎ¢¾µ»òÒÇ±í. An implement is a tool generally used outdoors, especially in gardening or farming, eg a plough, rake or spade. *implementÊÇÍ¨³£ÓÃì¶»§ÍâµÄ¹¤¾ß, ÓÈÖ¸Ô°ÒÕ»òÅ©×÷ÖĞÓÃµÄ, Èç¡¡¡¢ °Ò»òÇÂ. Device and gadget are more general terms. *deviceºÍgadget´ÊÒå½ÏÁıÍ³. Device is often used implying approval of a useful machine or instrument *device³£º¬°ıÒå, Ö¸Ä³»úÆ÷»ò¹¤¾ßºÜÓĞÓÃ´¦: a labour-saving device Ê¡Á¦µÄÆ÷¾ß *  a clever device for locking windows Ëø´°µÄÁéÇÉ×°ÖÃ. Gadget is more informal and can suggest disapproval *gadget½ÏÎªÍ¨Ë×, ¿Éº¬±áÒå: Their kitchen is full of the latest gadgets. ËûÃÇµÄ³ø·¿¾¡ÊÇ×îĞÂÊ½µÄÆ÷¾ß. *  All these modern gadgets are more trouble than they're worth. ËùÓĞÕâĞ©ÏÖ´ú»¯µÄ×°ÖÃ¶¼ÊÇ»¨Ç®ÂòÂé·³µÄÍæÒâ¶ù.

make at sb

make away with oneself 
commit suicide ×ÔÉ±. make away with sth = make off with sth.
make for sb/sth 
move in the direction of sb/sth; head for sb/sth ³¯Ä³ÈË[Ä³Îï]µÄ·½ÏòÒÆ¶¯: The ship made for the open sea. ÂÖ´¬Ê»Ïò¹«º£. * It's getting late; we'd better turn and make for home. ÌìÍíÁË, ÎÒÃÇ×îºÃÕÛ»Ø¼Ò°É. * When the interval came everyone made for the bar. Ä»¼äĞİÏ¢Ê±, ´ó¼Ò¶¼Ó¿Ïò¾Æ°É. * I turned and ran when I saw the bull making for (ie charging towards) me. ÎÒ¿´¼ûÄÇÍ·Å£ÏòÎÒ³åÀ´, ÎÒ¸Ï½ô×ªÉíÅÜ¿ªÁË. make for sth help to make sth possible; contribute to sth ÓĞÖúì¶×öÄ³ÊÂÎï; ÓĞÀûì¶Ä³ÊÂÎï: The large print makes for easier reading. ´óºÅ×ÖÌåÈİÒ×ÔÄ¶Á. * ÿConstant arguing doesn't make for a happy marriage. ¾­³£Õù³³²»Àûì¶Î¬ÏµºÍÃÀµÄ»éÒö. be `made for sb/each other be well suited to sb/each other ÍêÈ«ÊÊºÏÄ³ÈË[±Ë´ËÍêÈ«ÊÊÓ¦]: Ann and Robert seem (to be) made for each other. °²ºÍÂŞ²®ÌØÕæËÆÌìÉúµÄÒ»¶Ô.

man
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Man can be used, in a similar way to mankind, to mean `all men and women'. *manµÄÓÃ·¨¿ÉÓëmankindÏàÍ¬, Ö¸²»·ÖÄĞÅ®ËùÓĞµÄÈË. Many people consider this biased against women and avoid it by using humanity, the human race(singular) or humans, human beings, people (plural).Ğí¶àÈËÈÏÎªÕâÖÖÓÃ·¨ÊÇ¶ÔÅ®ĞÔµÄÆçÊÓ¶ø¼ÓÒÔ±ÜÃâ, ¸ÄÓÃhumanity¡¢ the human race£¨µ¥Êı£©»òhumans¡¢ human beings¡¢ people£¨¸´Êı£©.

may
/ meI; me/ modal v (neg ·ñ¶¨Ê½ may not, rare contracted form º±, ËõÔ¼Ê½ mayn't / meInt; ment/; pt might / maIt; maIt/, neg ·ñ¶¨Ê½ might not, rare contracted form º±, ËõÔ¼Ê½ mightn't / 5maItnt; `maItnt/)  1 (indicating permission ÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾ÔÊĞí¡¢ Ğí¿É): You may come if you wish. ÄãÒªÀ´¾ÍÀ´°É. * May I come in? ÎÒ¿ÉÒÔ½øÀ´Âğ? * Passengers may cross by the footbridge. ³Ë¿Í¿ÉÊ¹ÓÃ²½ĞĞÇÅ. =>Usage 1 ¼ûËù¸½ÓÃ·¨µÚ1Ïî.  2 (indicating possibility ÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾¿ÉÄÜ): This coat may be Peter's. ÕâÒ©Ò²ĞíÄÜÖÎÄãµÄ¿ÈËÔ. =>Usage 2 ¼ûËù¸½ÓÃ·¨µÚ2Ïî.  3 (indicating purpose ÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾Ä¿µÄ): I'll write today so that he may know when to expect us. ËıÓĞ¶à´óÄê¼ÍÁË? =>Usage 4 ¼ûËù¸½ÓÃ·¨µÚ4Ïî.  5 (used to express wishes and hopes ÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾Ô¸ÍûºÍÏ£Íû): May you both be very happy! ×£ÄãÃÇÁ©ĞÒ¸£! * Long may she live to enjoy her good fortune! may
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 PERMISSION (can2, could1, may1, might1) Ğí¿É£¨can2¡¢ could1¡¢ may1¡¢ might1£© (a) British speakers normally use can to give or request permission Ó¢¹úÈËÒ»°ãÓÃcan×ÖÀ´±íÊ¾×¼Ğí»òÇëÇóĞí¿É: You can come if you want to. ÄãÏëÀ´¾Í¿ÉÒÔÀ´. * Can I come too? ÎÒÒ²¿ÉÒÔÀ´Âğ? Could is more polite but is only used in questions ÓÃcouldÒ»´Ê¸ü¿ÍÆøĞ©, µ«Ö»ÓÃì¶ÒÉÎÊ¾äÖĞ: `Could I use your telephone?' `Yes, of course.' £àÎÒ¿ÉÒÔ½èÓÃÄãµÄµç»°Âğ?£§£àµ±È»¿ÉÒÔ.£§ May is formal *mayÊÇ½ÏÖ£ÖØµÄ´Ê: You may come if you wish. ÄãÔ¸ÒâÀ´¾Í¿ÉÒÔÀ´. However, US speakers often use may where British English has can µ«ÊÇÃÀ¹úÈË³£ÓÃmay, Ó¢¹úÈË¶àÓÃcan: May I sit down? ÎÒ¿ÉÒÔ×øÏÂÂğ? Both British and US speakers use could or might to suggest doubt, shyness, etc Ó¢ÃÀÁ½¹úµÄÈË¶¼ÓÃcould»òmightÀ´±íÊ¾»³ÒÉ¡¢ ĞßÇÓµÈ: Might I suggest another time? ÎÒ¿ÉÒÔ½¨ÒéÁíÕÒ¸öÊ±¼äÂğ? *  Could I arrange a meeting with the director? ÎÒ¿ÉÒÔÔ¼¼û¸ºÔğÈËÂğ? (b) In indirect questions, can becomes could and may becomes might ÔÚ¼ä½ÓÎÊ¾äÖĞ, Òª°Ñcan¸Ä³Écould, °Ñmay¸Ä³Émight: John asked if he could/might come too. Ô¼º²ÎÊ, ËûÊÇ·ñÒ²¿ÉÒÔÀ´.  2 POSSIBILITY (can2, could1, may1, might1) ¿ÉÄÜĞÔ£¨can2¡¢ could1¡¢ may1¡¢ might1£© (a) Could or might express more doubt or hesitation than may *could»òmight±Èmay¸üº¬»³ÒÉ»òÓÌÔ¥Ö®Òâ: That may be our taxi now! ÄÇÁ¾¿ÉÄÜ¾ÍÊÇÎÒÃÇµÄ¼Æ³Ì³µÁË. * That could/might be our taxi (but I doubt it). ÄÇÁ¾ÓĞ¿ÉÄÜÊÇÎÒÃÇµÄ¼Æ³Ì³µ£¨µ«ÎÒÓĞËù»³ÒÉ£©. (b) In questions and negative sentences can replaces may. ÔÚÒÉÎÊ¾äºÍ·ñ¶¨¾äÖĞ, ÓÃcan´úÌæmay. *Compare ÊÔ±È½Ï: It may be Bill's. ÄÇ¿ÉÄÜÊÇ±È¶ûµÄ. *  Can it be Bill's? It can't be Bill's. ÄÇ¿ÉÄÜÊÇ±È¶ûµÄÂğ? ²»¿ÉÄÜÊÇ±È¶ûµÄ. (c) Could have, may have or might have are used to show the possibility of something having happened in the past *could have¡¢ may have»òmight haveÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾¹ıÈ¥·¢Éú¹ıÄ³ÊÂµÄ¿ÉÄÜĞÔ: She could have forgotten to tell him. Ëı¿ÉÄÜÍü¼Ç¸æËßËûÁË. *  He may have lost his way. Ëû¿ÉÄÜÃÔÂ·ÁË. * He might just possibly have lost his keys. ËûÓĞ¿ÉÄÜ°ÑÔ¿³×¶ªÁË.  3 PURPOSE (may1, would1) Ä¿µÄ£¨may1¡¢ would1£© (a) May can be used after so that, in order that, to express present purpose *may¿ÉÓÃì¶so that¡¢ in order thatÖ®áá, ±íÊ¾ÏÖÔÚµÄÄ¿µÄ: I'll write so that he may know when to expect us. ÎÒÒªĞ´ĞÅºÃÈÃËûÖªµÀÎÒÃÇÊ²÷áÊ±ºòµ½. (b) to indicate a purpose in the past, might or would are used Òª±íÊ¾¹ıÈ¥Ä¿µÄ, ÔòÓÃmight»òwould: I wrote so that he might/would know when to expect us. ÎÒĞ´ĞÅºÃÈÃËûÖªµÀÎÒÃÇÊ²÷áÊ±ºòµ½. * He died so that others might/would live. ËûÎª±ğÈËÄÜ¹»»îÖø¶øÎşÉüÁË×Ô¼º.  4 ASKING FOR INFORMATION(may1, might1) Ñ¯ÎÊÇé¿ö£¨may1¡¢ might1£© (a) May(rather dated) and might are used to request information in an uncertain or a superior way *may£¨½Ï³Â¾É£©ºÍmightÓÃÒÔÑ¯ÎÊÇé¿ö, º¬ÎŞ°ÑÎÕ»ò¸ß°ÁµÄÓïÆø: Well, and who may/might `you be? ÄÇ÷á, ÄãÊÇË­ÄØ? (b) In indirect questions, only might is used ÔÚ¼ä½ÓÎÊ¾äÖĞ, Ö»ÓÃmight: Bill asked who `she might be. ±È¶ûÎÊËıÊÇË­.

mean

mean
/ mi:n; min/ n  1 condition, quality, course of action,etc that is halfway between two extremes ÖĞ¼ä; ÖĞÓ¹: You must find a mean between frankness and rudeness. ÄãÒªÔÚÌ¹³ÏÓëÌÆÍ»Ö®¼äÈ¡ÆäÖĞ.  2 (mathematics Êı) (a) midway point, quantity, etc between two extremes; average ÖĞÊı; Æ½¾ùÊı; Æ½¾ùÖµ: The mean of 13, 5 and 27 is found by adding them together and dividing by 3.  13¡¢ 5ºÍ27µÄÆ½¾ùÊı¿É½«ÈıÊıÏà¼ÓÔÙ³ıÒÔ3ÇóµÃ. (b) term between the first and the last of a series ±ÈÀıÖĞÏî: In 1:3 :: 3:9, the mean is 3. ÔÚ1:3 :: 3:9ÖĞ, ±ÈÀıÖĞÏîÊÇ3.  3 (idm Ï°Óï) the happy/golden mean moderate course of action ÖĞÓ¹Ö®µÀ.

/ 5meVE(r); `mZVL/ v  1 (a) [I, Ip, Tn, Tn.pr, Tn.p] ~ (sth) (up) find the size, length, volume, etc of (sth) by comparing it with a standard unit Á¿¶È; ²âÁ¿£¨Ä³Îï£©: Can you measure accurately with this ruler? man

ÄãÒÔÎªÎÒ»á½è¸øÄã50Ó¢°÷, Äã×¼ÊÇ·èÁË! bear in mind that... => bear2. bear/keep sb/sth in `mind remember sb/sth ¼Ç×¡Ä³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]: We have no vacancies now, but we'll certainly bear your application in mind. / maIn; maIn/ n  1 excavation (with shafts, galleries,etc) made in the earth for extracting coal, mineral ores, precious stones, etc ¿ó¾®; ÏïµÀ; ¿ó: a `coal-mine Ãº¿ó * a `gold-mine ½ğ¿ó * The inspector went down the mine. ¼à²ìÔ±ÒÑÏÂµ½¿ó¾®ÀïÁË. * [attrib ×÷¶¨Óï] a `mineworker ¿ó¹¤. missing 
adj  1 (a) that cannot be found or that is not in its usual place; lost ÕÒ²»µ½µÄ; ²»ÔÚÔ­´¦µÄ; Ê§È¥µÄ: The book had two pages missing/two missing pages. mistake
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Mistake, error, blunder, fault and defect all refer to something done incorrectly or improperly. *mistake¡¢ error¡¢ blunder¡¢ fault¡¢ defect ¶¼ÓÃÒÔÖ¸Ã»ÓĞ×ö¶Ô»ò×öµÃ²»Í×µÄÊÂÎï. Mistake is the most general, used of everyday situations *mistake´ÊÒå×îÁıÍ³, ¿ÉÓÃì¶ÈÕ³£¸÷ÖÖÇé¿ö: Your essay is full of mistakes. ÄãµÄÎÄÕÂ´íÎóºÜ¶à. *  It was a mistake to go there on holiday. ÅÜµ½ÄÇ¶ù¶È¼ÙÕæÊÇÊ§²ß.  Error is more formal *error½ÏÎÄ: an error in your calculations Äã¼ÆËãÖĞ³öÏÖµÄ´íÎó *  a technical error¼¼ÊõĞÔ´íÎó. A blunder is a careless mistake, often unnecessary or resulting from misjudgement *blunderÊÇ´ÖĞÄµÄ´íÎó, ³£Îª²»¸ÃÓĞµÄ»ò³öì¶ÅĞ¶Ï´íÎó: I made a terrible blunder in introducing her to my husband. ÎÒ°ÑËı½éÉÜ¸øÎÒµÄÕÉ·òÊÇ·¸ÁËÒ»¸ö¼«´óµÄ´íÎó. Fault emphasizes a person's responsibility for a mistake *fault²àÖØì¶Ôì³É´íÎóµÄ¸öÈËÔğÈÎ: The child broke the window, but it was his parents' fault for letting him play football indoors. º¢×Ó°Ñ´°»§´òÆÆÁË, µ«ÊÇÈÃËûÔÚÎİÀïÌß×ãÇòÊÇËû¸¸Ä¸µÄ¹ı´í. Fault can also indicate an imperfection in a person or thing *fault»¹¿ÉÖ¸ÈË»òÎïµÄÈ±µã: He has many faults, but vanity is not one of them. ËûÓĞºÜ¶àÈ±µã, µ«²¢Ã»ÓĞĞéÈÙĞÄ. * an electrical fault µçÂ·µÄ¹ÊÕÏ. A defect is more serious *defectÖ¸¸üÎªÑÏÖØµÄÈ±Ïİ: The new car had to be withdrawn from the market because of a mechanical defect. ÄÇÖÖĞÂÆû³µÒòÓĞ»úĞµÈ±ÏİÖ»ºÃ³·³öÊĞ³¡.

NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Usually the preposition in is used with morning/afternoon/evening, on their own and in combination with other time expressions ½é´ÊinÍ¨³£Óëmorning/afternoon/eveningµÈ´ÊÁ¬ÓÃ, Ò²Óëº¬ÕâĞ©´ÊµÄÊ±¼ä´Ê×éÁ¬ÓÃ: in the morning/afternoon/evening ÔÚÉÏÎç[ÏÂÎç/ÍíÉÏ] * at 3 o'clock in the afternoon ÏÂÎçÈıµã *  on the 4th of September in the morning ÔÚ9ÔÂ4ÈÕÉÏÎç. In is also used with the adjectives early and late *inÒ²ÓëĞÎÈİ´ÊearlyºÍlateÁ¬ÓÃ: in the early/late morning Çå³¿[½üÎçÊ±·Ö]. With other adjectives and in certain other expressions on is used ÓëÆäËûĞÎÈİ´Ê¼°Ä³Ğ©´Ê×éÁ¬ÓÃÊ±ĞèÓÃon: on a cool morning in spring ´ºÌìµÄÒ»¸öÁ¹Ë¬µÄÔç³¿ *  on Monday afternoon ÔÚĞÇÆÚÒ»ÏÂÎç *  on the previous/following evening ÔÚÍ·Ìì[µÚ¶şÌì]ÍíÉÏ *  on the morning of the 4th of September ÔÚ9ÔÂ4ÈÕµÄÉÏÎç. much
Notice the difference between little/few and a little/a few. ×¢Òâlittle/fewºÍa little/a fewÕâÁ½×é´ÊµÄÇø±ğ. If we say, `I have little money and few interests', we sound disappointed and negative. ÈôËµ: £àI have little money and few interests£¨ÎÒÃ»ÓĞÊ²÷áÇ®, Ò²Ã»ÓĞÊ²÷á°®ºÃ£©£§, ÑÔÓÌâêÈ»ÈôÊ§, º¬·ñ¶¨Òå. If we say, `I have a little money and a few interests', we sound more positive. ÈôËµ: £àI have a little money and a few interests£¨ÎÒÓĞµã¶ùÇ®, Ò²ÓĞĞ©°®ºÃ£©£§, Ôòº¬¿Ï¶¨Òå. Compare ÊÔ±È½Ï: He's lived here a long time but has few friends £¨ËûÔÚÕâ¶ù×¡ÁËºÜ³¤Ê±¼ä, ¿ÉÊÇÃ»Ê²÷áÅóÓÑ£©ºÍHe's lived here a short time but already has a few friends £¨ËûÔÚÕâ¶ù×¡µÃÊ±¼äºÜ¶Ì, ¿ÉÊÇÒÑ¾­ÓĞĞ©ÅóÓÑÁË£©. 2A lot of can also be used in questions *a lot of Òà¿ÉÓÃì¶ÒÉÎÊ¾ä: Have we got a lot of time/cards left? £¨ÎÒÃÇÊ£ÏÂµÄÊ±¼ä[¿¨Æ¬]¶à²»¶à?£© It suggests that the speaker knows that there is/are some left and wants to know whether the amount/number is big or small. Õâ¾ä»°µÄº¬ÒåÊÇ·¢ÎÊÕßÖªµÀÓĞĞ©Ê£Óà, »¹ÏëÖªµÀÊ£ÓàµÄÊıÁ¿ÊÇ¶àÊÇÉÙ. 3The comparative and superlative forms of much, many, and a lot of are more and (the) most. *much¡¢ many¡¢ a lot ofµÄ±È½Ï¼¶ÊÇmore, ×î¸ß¼¶ÊÇ(the) most. For little the comparative and superlative forms are less and (the) least and for few they are fewer and (the) fewest. *littleµÄ±È½Ï¼¶ÊÇless, ×î¸ß¼¶ÊÇ(the) least; fewµÄ±È½Ï¼¶ÊÇfewer, ×î¸ß¼¶ÊÇ(the) fewest.
much
/ mQtF; mQtF/ adv to a great extent or degree ºÜ; ·Ç³£; ÔÚºÜ´ó³Ì¶ÈÉÏ.  1 (often used with negative vs ³£Óë·ñ¶¨Ê½¶¯´ÊÁ¬ÓÃ): She didn't enjoy the film (very) much. n  1 (mathematics Êı) quantity which contains another quantity an exact number of times ±¶Êı: 14, 21 and 28 are multiples of 7. 14¡¢ 21¡¢ 28¶¼ÊÇ7µÄ±¶Êı. * 30 is a common multiple of 2, 3, 5, 6, 10 and 15. 30ÊÇ2¡¢ 3¡¢ 5¡¢ 6¡¢ 10¡¢ 15µÄ¹«±¶Êı. * least/lowest common multiple, ie smallest quantity that contains two or more given quantities exactly (usu shortened to LCM, eg The LCM of 4, 5, 6, 10 and 12 is 60) ×îĞ¡¹«±¶Êı£¨ÂÔ×÷LCM, Èç4¡¢ 5¡¢ 6¡¢ 10¡¢ 12µÄ×îĞ¡¹«±¶ÊıÊÇ60£©.  2 (also ,multiple `store) (esp Brit) shop with many branches throughout a country Á¬ËøÉÌµê.

must
/ mEst; mEst, strong form Ç¿¶ÁÊ½ mQst; mQst/ modal v (neg ·ñ¶¨Ê½ must not, contracted form ËõÔ¼Ê½ mustn't / 5mQsnt; `mQsnt/)  1 (a) (indicating obligation ±íÊ¾±ØÒª): I must go to the bank to get some money. ÎÒµÃµ½ÒøĞĞÈ¥È¡Ğ©Ç®. * When you enter the building you must show the guard your pass. ½øÈë´óÂ¥Ê±ĞëÏò¾¯ÎÀ³öÊ¾Í¨ĞĞÖ¤. * Cars must not park in front of the entrance. Èë¿Ú´¦²»µÃÍ£·ÅÆû³µ. * You mustn't open the oven door before the cake is ready. ±ıÎ´Êì²»µÃ´ò¿ª¿¾ÏäµÄÃÅ. * We mustn't be late, must we? ÎÒÃÇ²»ÄÜ³Ùµ½, ÊÇ°É? * `Must you go so soon?' `Yes, I must.' £àÄãÒ»¶¨µÃÕâ÷áÔç¾Í×ßÂğ?£§£àÊÇµÄ, ±ØĞëÕâ÷áÔç.£§ =>Usage 1 ¼ûËù¸½ÓÃ·¨µÚ1Ïî. (b) (indicating advice or recommendation ±íÊ¾È°¸æ»ò½¨Òé): We must see what the authorities have to say. ÎÒÃÇÓ¦¸Ã¿´¿´µ±¾ÖÔõ÷áËµ. * I must ask you not to do that again. ÎÒµÃÈ°Äã²»ÒªÔÙ×öÄÇÖÖÊÂÇéÁË. =>Usage 2 ¼ûËù¸½ÓÃ·¨µÚ2Ïî.  2 (drawing a logical conclusion ×ö³öÂß¼­ÍÆ¶Ï): You must be hungry after your long walk. Äã×ßÁËÄÇ÷á³¤µÄÂ·, Ò»¶¨¶öÁË°É. * She must be having a lot of problems with the language. ËıÔÚÓïÑÔÉÏÒ»¶¨ÓĞºÜ¶àÀ§ÄÑ. * You must be Mr Smith  I was told to expect you. Äã×¼ÊÇÊ·ÃÜË¹ÏÈÉú°É--ÎÒÊÇ·Ô¸ÀÀ´½ÓÄãµÄ. * They must be twins. ËûÃÇÒ»¶¨ÊÇË«°ûÌ¥. * He must have known (ie Surely he knew) what she wanted. Ëûµ±Ê±¿Ï¶¨ÖªµÀËıĞèÒªÊ²÷á. * We must have read the same report. must

must
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 OBLIGATION (must, need1,2, have to, ought to, should1) ÒåÎñ»òÔğÈÎ£¨must¡¢ need1, 2¡¢ have to¡¢ ought to¡¢ should£© (a) Must is used to show that the speaker orders or expects something to be done *mustÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾Ëµ»°ÕßÃüÁî»òÆÚ´ı×ö³ÉÄ³ÊÂ: The children must be back by 4 o'clock. º¢×Ó±ØĞë4µãÖÓÒÔÇ°»ØÀ´. *  I must go now, ie I feel obliged to go. ÎÒÏÖÔÚµÃ×ßÁË, ¼´ÎÒ¾õµÃÓĞ´Ë±ØÒª. Need to (informal have to) is used when somebody else is giving orders or controlling events *need to£¨Í¨Ë×ÓÃ´ÊÎªhave to£©ÓÃì¶ËûÈË·¢³öÖ¸Áî»ò²Ù×İµÄÇé¿öÏÂ: You need to/have to pass a special exam to get into the school. ÄãÒªÉÏÄÇËùÑ§Ğ£µÃÍ¨¹ıÒ»´ÎÌØ±ğµÄ¿¼ÊÔ. *  I have to go now, ie something (or somebody else) requires it. ÎÒÏÖÔÚµÃ×ßÁË, ¼´Ä³ÊÂ»òÄ³ÈËÒªÇóÎÒÈç´Ë. Ought to and should indicate that the speaker is giving an order, but suggest that he or she is not sure it will be obeyed *ought toºÍshould±íÊ¾Ëµ»°Õß·¢³öÖ¸Áî, µ«°µº¬¶Ô·½ÊÇ·ñÌı´Ó²¢ÎŞ°ÑÎÕÖ®Òâ: She really ought to/should be leaving now. ËıÏÖÔÚ¿ÉÕæ¸Ã×ßÁË. *  You ought to/should apologize (though I'm not sure you will). ÄãÓ¦¸ÃµÀÇ¸£¨ËäÈ»ÎÒ²»ÖªµÀÄãÊÇ·ñÕâÑù×ö£©. (b) Mustn't (and oughtn't to, shouldn't) are used when the speaker wants somebody not to do something*mustn't£¨ºÍoughtn't to¡¢ shouldn't£©ÓÃì¶Ëµ»°ÕßÒªÄ³ÈË²»×öÄ³ÊÂ: You mustn't leave the gate open. Äã²»Òª³¨Öø´óÃÅ. *  You oughtn't to/shouldn't neglect the garden. Äã²»Òª²»¹Ü»¨Ô°. Needn't and don't have to mean that there is a lack of obligation to do something *needn' tºÍdon' t have toÒâÖ¸Ã»ÓĞ×öÄ³ÊÂµÄÒåÎñ»òÔğÈÎ: You needn't/don't have to arrive early. (Cf You mustn't arrive early.) Äã²»±ØÔçÀ´. £¨²Î¿´: Äã²»ÒªÔçÀ´.£© (c) In indirect commands, had to replaces must ÔÚ¼ä½ÓÖ¸ÁîÖĞÓÃhad toÈ¡´úmust: Mother said that the children had to be back by 4 o'clock. (Cf Mary said he ought to/should apologize.) Ä¸Ç×ËµÁËº¢×Ó4µãÒÔÇ°±ØĞë»ØÀ´. £¨²Î¿´: ÂêÀöËµËûÓ¦¸ÃµÀÇ¸.£©  2 ADVICE (must, have got to, ought to, should1) È°¸æ»ò½¨Òé£¨must¡¢ have got to¡¢ ought to¡¢ should1£© (a) Must (informal have got to) is used to advise or recommend *must£¨Í¨Ë×ÓÃ´ÊÎªhave got to£©ÓÃÒÔÌá³öÈ°¸æ»ò½¨Òé: You simply must see that film. Äã¿ÉµÃ¿´¿´Õâ²¿µçÓ°. *  You've got to take life more seriously. Äã¶Ô´ıÉú»îÒªÑÏËàÒ»Ğ©. Ought to and should suggest that the speaker is less confident the advice will be taken *ought toºÍshouldº¬ÓĞËµ»°Õß¶ÔÈ°¸æÖ®ÊÇ·ñ½ÓÊÜ¸üÎŞ°ÑÎÕÖ®Òâ: You really ought to/should do something about that cough! Äã¿ÈËÔÄÇ÷áÀ÷º¦, ÕæµÃÖÎÒ»ÖÎÁË! (b) To advise somebody not to do something, mustn't, oughtn't to and shouldn't are used È°Ä³ÈË²»×öÄ³ÊÂÊ±, ÓÃmustn't¡¢ oughtn't to¡¢ shouldn't: You mustn't/oughtn't to/shouldn't miss this opportunity. Äã²»¿É[²»¸Ã/²»Ó¦]´í¹ıÕâ¸ö»ú»á. (c) In indirect speech, the same rules apply as for OBLIGATION. ÔÚ¼ä½ÓÒıÓÃÓïÖĞ,Ç°ÊöÓÃì¶±íÊ¾ÒåÎñ»òÔğÈÎµÄ¹æÔòÒ²ÊÊÓÃì¶´Ë.  3 DRAWING CONCLUSIONS (must, have to, ought to, should1) ×÷½áÂÛ£¨must¡¢ have to¡¢ ought to¡¢ should1£© (a) Must and have to (informal) are used when drawing a conclusion about which there is no doubt *mustºÍhave to£¨½ÏÍ¨Ë×£©ÓÃì¶ºÁÎŞ»³ÒÉµÄ½áÂÛ: He must be/has to be the wanted man: he's exactly like his picture. ËûÒ»¶¨ÊÇÊÜÍ¨¼©µÄÄÇ¸öÄĞ×Ó: ËûºÍÕÕÆ¬ÉÏµÄÈËÒ»Ä£Ò»Ñù. Ought to and should indicate that the speaker is being more tentative *ought toºÍshould±íÊ¾Ëµ»°ÕßÓĞ½Ï´óµÄÊÔÌ½ĞÔ: He ought to/should be here in time  he started early enough. Ëû¸Ã[Ó¦]°´Ê±µ½ÕâÀï--Ëû³ö·¢µÃ¹»ÔçµÄ. (b) To show that a conclusion cannot be drawn, can't is used ±íÊ¾ÎŞ·¨¶¨ÂÛÔòÓÃcan't: He can't be the wanted man. Ëû²»»áÊÇÄÇ¸ö±»Í¨¼©µÄÄĞ×Ó. *  He can't (surely) get here in time. Ëû£¨¿Ï¶¨£©²»ÄÜ¼°Ê±¸Ïµ½ÕâÀï. (c) Must have, ought to have and should have are used to draw a conclusion from some past event *must have¡¢ ought to have¡¢ should haveÓÃÒÔ¶ÔÄ³¼ş¹ıÈ¥µÄÊÂÇé×÷½áÂÛ: She must have received the parcel: I sent it by registered post. ËıÒ»¶¨ÒÑ¾­ÊÕµ½°ü¹üÁË, ÎÒÊÇÓÃ¹ÒºÅ¼ÄµÄ.

A machine consists of moving parts powered by electricity, etc and is designed for a specific job. *machineÊÇÓÉµçÁ¦µÈÇı¶¯µÄ»úÆ÷, ÊÇÎª×öÄ³ÖÖ¹¤×÷¶øÉè¼ÆµÄ. An (electrical) appliance is a machine used in the house, such as awashing-machine or dishwasher. *(electrical) applianceÊÇ¼ÒÓÃµçÆ÷, ÈçÏ´ÒÂ»ú»òÏ´µú»ú. An apparatus is a system of connected machines, wires, etc *apparatusÊÇÏàÁª½áµÄ»úÆ÷¡¢ µ¼ÏßµÈÏµÍ³: the apparatus for lighting the stage ÎèÌ¨ÕÕÃ÷Éè±¸. A tool is an object held in the hand, often used by people in their jobs, eg a hammer, drill or spanner. *toolÊÇÊÖ³Ö¹¤¾ß, ³£Îª¸É»î¶ùµÄÈËÓÃµÄ, Èç¡¡×Ó¡¢ ×ê»ò°â×Ó. An instrument is a tool designed for a technical task, eg a surgeon's knife. *instrumentÊÇÎª¼¼Êõ¹¤×÷Éè¼ÆµÄ¹¤¾ß, ÈçÊÖÊõµ¶. It may have some moving parts and be used in a technical operation, eg a microscope or meter. *instrument¿ÉÄÜÓĞÄ³Ğ©ÔË×ª²¿¼ş²¢ÓÃì¶¼¼Êõ²Ù×÷, ÈçÏÔÎ¢¾µ»òÒÇ±í. An implement is a tool generally used outdoors, especially in gardening or farming, eg a plough, rake or spade. *implementÊÇÍ¨³£ÓÃì¶»§ÍâµÄ¹¤¾ß, ÓÈÖ¸Ô°ÒÕ»òÅ©×÷ÖĞÓÃµÄ, Èç¡¡¡¢ °Ò»òÇÂ. Device and gadget are more general terms. *deviceºÍgadget´ÊÒå½ÏÁıÍ³. Device is often used implying approval of a useful machine or instrument *device³£º¬°ıÒå, Ö¸Ä³»úÆ÷»ò¹¤¾ßºÜÓĞÓÃ´¦: a labour-saving device Ê¡Á¦µÄÆ÷¾ß *  a clever device for locking windows Ëø´°µÄÁéÇÉ×°ÖÃ. Gadget is more informal and can suggest disapproval *gadget½ÏÎªÍ¨Ë×, ¿Éº¬±áÒå: Their kitchen is full of the latest gadgets. ËûÃÇµÄ³ø·¿¾¡ÊÇ×îĞÂÊ½µÄÆ÷¾ß. *  All these modern gadgets are more trouble than they're worth. ËùÓĞÕâĞ©ÏÖ´ú»¯µÄ×°ÖÃ¶¼ÊÇ»¨Ç®ÂòÂé·³µÄÍæÒâ¶ù.

man
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Man can be used, in a similar way to mankind, to mean `all men and women'. *manµÄÓÃ·¨¿ÉÓëmankindÏàÍ¬, Ö¸²»·ÖÄĞÅ®ËùÓĞµÄÈË. mark
/ mB:k; mBrk/ v  1 [Tn, Tn.pr] ~ A (with B); ~ B on A make (a mark or marks) on sth ÔÚÄ³ÎïÉÏ×ö£¨¼ÇºÅ£©: mark one's name on one's clothes/mark one's clothes with one's name ÔÚ×Ô¼ºµÄÒÂ·şÉÏ±êÉÏ×Ô¼ºµÄÃû×Ö * The route has been marked so that it is easy to follow. (b) ~ of sth (to sb) situation, problem or result that arouses the specified emotion ÒıÆğÄ³ÖÖÇé¸ĞµÄÇé¿ö¡¢ ÎÊÌâ»ò½á¹û: matters of growing public concern ¹«ÖÚÈÕÒæ¹ØÇĞµÄÊÂÇé * This discussion is on a matter of considerable interest to me. Õâ´ÎÌÖÂÛµÄÊÇ¶ÔÎÒºÜÓĞ¹ØÏµµÄÊÂ.  2 [U] (a) physical substance in general (contrasted with mind or spirit) ÎïÖÊ£¨Óë¾«ÉñÏà¶Ô£©: inert matter ÎŞÉúÃüµÄÎïÖÊ * to study the properties of matter ÑĞ¾¿ÎïÖÊµÄÌØĞÔ. * The universe is composed of matter. may
/ meI; me/ modal v (neg ·ñ¶¨Ê½ may not, rare contracted form º±, ËõÔ¼Ê½ mayn't / meInt; ment/; pt might / maIt; maIt/, neg ·ñ¶¨Ê½ might not, rare contracted form º±, ËõÔ¼Ê½ mightn't / 5maItnt; `maItnt/)  1 (indicating permission ÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾ÔÊĞí¡¢ Ğí¿É): You may come if you wish. ÄãÒªÀ´¾ÍÀ´°É. * May I come in? ÎÒ¿ÉÒÔ½øÀ´Âğ? * Passengers may cross by the footbridge. ³Ë¿Í¿ÉÊ¹ÓÃ²½ĞĞÇÅ. =>Usage 1 ¼ûËù¸½ÓÃ·¨µÚ1Ïî.  2 (indicating possibility ÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾¿ÉÄÜ): This coat may be Peter's. Õâ¼ş´óÒÂ¿ÉÄÜÊÇ±ËµÃµÄ. * That may or may not be true. ÄÇ¿ÉÄÜÊÇÊµÇé, Ò²¿ÉÄÜ²»ÊÇ. * He may have (ie Perhaps he has) missed his train. Ëû¿ÉÄÜÃ»¸ÏÉÏ»ğ³µ. * This medicine may cure your cough. ÕâÒ©Ò²ĞíÄÜÖÎÄãµÄ¿ÈËÔ. =>Usage 2 ¼ûËù¸½ÓÃ·¨µÚ2Ïî.  3 (indicating purpose ÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾Ä¿µÄ): I'll write today so that he may know when to expect us. ÎÒ½ñÌì¾ÍĞ´ĞÅºÃÈÃËûÖªµÀÎÒÃÇÊ²÷áÊ±ºòµ½. =>Usage 3 ¼ûËù¸½ÓÃ·¨µÚ3Ïî.  4 (dated ¾É) (asking for information ÓÃì¶Ñ¯ÎÊÇé¿ö): Well, who may `you be? Î¹, ÄãÊÇË­Ñ½? * How old may `she be? ËıÓĞ¶à´óÄê¼ÍÁË? =>Usage 4 ¼ûËù¸½ÓÃ·¨µÚ4Ïî.  5 (used to express wishes and hopes ÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾Ô¸ÍûºÍÏ£Íû): May you both be very happy! ×£ÄãÃÇÁ©ĞÒ¸£! * Long may she live to enjoy her good fortune! may
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 PERMISSION (can2, could1, may1, might1) Ğí¿É£¨can2¡¢ could1¡¢ may1¡¢ might1£© (a) British speakers normally use can to give or request permission Ó¢¹úÈËÒ»°ãÓÃcan×ÖÀ´±íÊ¾×¼Ğí»òÇëÇóĞí¿É: You can come if you want to. ÄãÏëÀ´¾Í¿ÉÒÔÀ´. * Can I come too? ÎÒÒ²¿ÉÒÔÀ´Âğ? Could is more polite but is only used in questions ÓÃcouldÒ»´Ê¸ü¿ÍÆøĞ©, µ«Ö»ÓÃì¶ÒÉÎÊ¾äÖĞ: `Could I use your telephone?' `Yes, of course.' £àÎÒ¿ÉÒÔ½èÓÃÄãµÄµç»°Âğ?£§£àµ±È»¿ÉÒÔ.£§ May is formal *mayÊÇ½ÏÖ£ÖØµÄ´Ê: You may come if you wish. ÄãÔ¸ÒâÀ´¾Í¿ÉÒÔÀ´. However, US speakers often use may where British English has can µ«ÊÇÃÀ¹úÈË³£ÓÃmay, Ó¢¹úÈË¶àÓÃcan: May I sit down? ÎÒ¿ÉÒÔ×øÏÂÂğ? Both British and US speakers use could or might to suggest doubt, shyness, etc Ó¢ÃÀÁ½¹úµÄÈË¶¼ÓÃcould»òmightÀ´±íÊ¾»³ÒÉ¡¢ ĞßÇÓµÈ: Might I suggest another time? ÎÒ¿ÉÒÔ½¨ÒéÁíÕÒ¸öÊ±¼äÂğ? *  Could I arrange a meeting with the director? ÎÒ¿ÉÒÔÔ¼¼û¸ºÔğÈËÂğ? (b) In indirect questions, can becomes could and may becomes might ÔÚ¼ä½ÓÎÊ¾äÖĞ, Òª°Ñcan¸Ä³Écould, °Ñmay¸Ä³Émight: John asked if he could/might come too. Ô¼º²ÎÊ, ËûÊÇ·ñÒ²¿ÉÒÔÀ´.  2 POSSIBILITY (can2, could1, may1, might1) ¿ÉÄÜĞÔ£¨can2¡¢ could1¡¢ may1¡¢ might1£© (a) Could or might express more doubt or hesitation than may *could»òmight±Èmay¸üº¬»³ÒÉ»òÓÌÔ¥Ö®Òâ: That may be our taxi now! ÄÇÁ¾¿ÉÄÜ¾ÍÊÇÎÒÃÇµÄ¼Æ³Ì³µÁË. * That could/might be our taxi (but I doubt it). ÄÇÁ¾ÓĞ¿ÉÄÜÊÇÎÒÃÇµÄ¼Æ³Ì³µ£¨µ«ÎÒÓĞËù»³ÒÉ£©. (b) In questions and negative sentences can replaces may. ÔÚÒÉÎÊ¾äºÍ·ñ¶¨¾äÖĞ, ÓÃcan´úÌæmay. *Compare ÊÔ±È½Ï: It may be Bill's. ÄÇ¿ÉÄÜÊÇ±È¶ûµÄ. *  Can it be Bill's? It can't be Bill's. ÄÇ¿ÉÄÜÊÇ±È¶ûµÄÂğ? ²»¿ÉÄÜÊÇ±È¶ûµÄ. (c) Could have, may have or might have are used to show the possibility of something having happened in the past *could have¡¢ may have»òmight haveÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾¹ıÈ¥·¢Éú¹ıÄ³ÊÂµÄ¿ÉÄÜĞÔ: She could have forgotten to tell him. Ëı¿ÉÄÜÍü¼Ç¸æËßËûÁË. *  He may have lost his way. Ëû¿ÉÄÜÃÔÂ·ÁË. * He might just possibly have lost his keys. ËûÓĞ¿ÉÄÜ°ÑÔ¿³×¶ªÁË.  3 PURPOSE (may1, would1) Ä¿µÄ£¨may1¡¢ would1£© (a) May can be used after so that, in order that, to express present purpose *may¿ÉÓÃì¶so that¡¢ in order thatÖ®áá, ±íÊ¾ÏÖÔÚµÄÄ¿µÄ: I'll write so that he may know when to expect us. ÎÒÒªĞ´ĞÅºÃÈÃËûÖªµÀÎÒÃÇÊ²÷áÊ±ºòµ½. (b) to indicate a purpose in the past, might or would are used Òª±íÊ¾¹ıÈ¥Ä¿µÄ, ÔòÓÃmight»òwould: I wrote so that he might/would know when to expect us. ÎÒĞ´ĞÅºÃÈÃËûÖªµÀÎÒÃÇÊ²÷áÊ±ºòµ½. * He died so that others might/would live. ËûÎª±ğÈËÄÜ¹»»îÖø¶øÎşÉüÁË×Ô¼º.  4 ASKING FOR INFORMATION(may1, might1) Ñ¯ÎÊÇé¿ö£¨may1¡¢ might1£© (a) May(rather dated) and might are used to request information in an uncertain or a superior way *may£¨½Ï³Â¾É£©ºÍmightÓÃÒÔÑ¯ÎÊÇé¿ö, º¬ÎŞ°ÑÎÕ»ò¸ß°ÁµÄÓïÆø: Well, and who may/might `you be? mean
/ mi:n; min/ n  1 condition, quality, course of action,etc that is halfway between two extremes ÖĞ¼ä; ÖĞÓ¹: You must find a mean between frankness and rudeness. ÄãÒªÔÚÌ¹³ÏÓëÌÆÍ»Ö®¼äÈ¡ÆäÖĞ.  2 (mathematics Êı) (a) midway point, quantity, etc between two extremes; average ÖĞÊı; Æ½¾ùÊı; Æ½¾ùÖµ: The mean of 13, 5 and 27 is found by adding them together and dividing by 3.  13¡¢ 5ºÍ27µÄÆ½¾ùÊı¿É½«ÈıÊıÏà¼ÓÔÙ³ıÒÔ3ÇóµÃ. (b) term between the first and the last of a series ±ÈÀıÖĞÏî: In 1:3 :: 3:9, the mean is 3. ÔÚ1:3 :: 3:9ÖĞ, ±ÈÀıÖĞÏîÊÇ3.  3 (idm Ï°Óï) the happy/golden mean moderate course of action ÖĞÓ¹Ö®µÀ.

means
/ mi:nz; minz/ n [sing or pl v]  1 action by which a result is brought about; method(s) ÊÖ¶Î; ·½·¨: use illegal means to get a passport ÓÃ·Ç·¨ÊÖ¶Î»ñÈ¡»¤ÕÕ * This money wasn't earned by honest means. / maInd; maInd/ v  1 [Tn] take care of or attend to (sb/sth) ÕÕ¿´, ÁôĞÄ£¨Ä³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]£©: mind the baby ÕÕÁÏÓ¤¶ù * Mind my bike while I go into the shop, please. mistake
/ mI5steIk; mE`stek/ n  1 wrong idea or opinion; misconception ´íÎóµÄÏë·¨»ò¼û½â; Îó½â; Îó»á: You can't arrest me! There must be some mistake! ÄãÃÇ²»ÄÜ´ş²¶ÎÒ! ÎÒ´íÄÃÁËÄãµÄÊÖÌá°ü, »¹ÒÔÎªÊÇÎÒµÄÄØ. and ,no mi`stake (infml ¿Ú) without any doubt ºÁÎŞÒÉÎÊ; µÄÈ·: It's hot today and no mistake! ½ñÌìÈ·ÊµºÜÈÈ! ,make no mi`stake (about sth) (infml ¿Ú) do not be misled into thinking otherwise ±ğÎó»á; ±ğÎó½â: Susan seems very quiet, but make no mistake (about it), she has a terrible temper! mistake
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Mistake, error, blunder, fault and defect all refer to something done incorrectly or improperly. *mistake¡¢ error¡¢ blunder¡¢ fault¡¢ defect ¶¼ÓÃÒÔÖ¸Ã»ÓĞ×ö¶Ô»ò×öµÃ²»Í×µÄÊÂÎï. Mistake is the most general, used of everyday situations *mistake´ÊÒå×îÁıÍ³, ¿ÉÓÃì¶ÈÕ³£¸÷ÖÖÇé¿ö: Your essay is full of mistakes. ÄãµÄÎÄÕÂ´íÎóºÜ¶à. *  It was a mistake to go there on holiday. ÅÜµ½ÄÇ¶ù¶È¼ÙÕæÊÇÊ§²ß.  Error is more formal *error½ÏÎÄ: an error in your calculations Äã¼ÆËãÖĞ³öÏÖµÄ´íÎó *  a technical error¼¼ÊõĞÔ´íÎó. A blunder is a careless mistake, often unnecessary or resulting from misjudgement *blunderÊÇ´ÖĞÄµÄ´íÎó, ³£Îª²»¸ÃÓĞµÄ»ò³öì¶ÅĞ¶Ï´íÎó: I made a terrible blunder in introducing her to my husband. ÎÒ°ÑËı½éÉÜ¸øÎÒµÄÕÉ·òÊÇ·¸ÁËÒ»¸ö¼«´óµÄ´íÎó. Fault emphasizes a person's responsibility for a mistake *fault²àÖØì¶Ôì³É´íÎóµÄ¸öÈËÔğÈÎ: The child broke the window, but it was his parents' fault for letting him play football indoors. º¢×Ó°Ñ´°»§´òÆÆÁË, µ«ÊÇÈÃËûÔÚÎİÀïÌß×ãÇòÊÇËû¸¸Ä¸µÄ¹ı´í. Fault can also indicate an imperfection in a person or thing *fault»¹¿ÉÖ¸ÈË»òÎïµÄÈ±µã: He has many faults, but vanity is not one of them. ËûÓĞºÜ¶àÈ±µã, µ«²¢Ã»ÓĞĞéÈÙĞÄ. * an electrical fault µçÂ·µÄ¹ÊÕÏ. A defect is more serious *defectÖ¸¸üÎªÑÏÖØµÄÈ±Ïİ: The new car had to be withdrawn from the market because of a mechanical defect. ÄÇÖÖĞÂÆû³µÒòÓĞ»úĞµÈ±ÏİÖ»ºÃ³·³öÊĞ³¡.
mistake
/ mI5steIk; mE`stek/ v (pt mistook / mI5stUk; mEs`tJk/, pp mistaken / mIs5teIkEn; mE`stekEn/)  1 [Tn, Tw] be wrong or get a wrong idea about (sb/sth) Åª´í¡¢ Îó½â»òÎó»á£¨Ä³ÈË£©»ò£¨Ä³ÊÂÎï£©µÄÒâË¼: I must have mistaken your meaning/what you meant. In is also used with the adjectives early and late *inÒ²ÓëĞÎÈİ´ÊearlyºÍlateÁ¬ÓÃ: in the early/late morning Çå³¿[½üÎçÊ±·Ö]. With other adjectives and in certain other expressions on is used ÓëÆäËûĞÎÈİ´Ê¼°Ä³Ğ©´Ê×éÁ¬ÓÃÊ±ĞèÓÃon: on a cool morning in spring ´ºÌìµÄÒ»¸öÁ¹Ë¬µÄÔç³¿ *  on Monday afternoon ÔÚĞÇÆÚÒ»ÏÂÎç *  on the previous/following evening ÔÚÍ·Ìì[µÚ¶şÌì]ÍíÉÏ *  on the morning of the 4th of September ÔÚ9ÔÂ4ÈÕµÄÉÏÎç. / mQtF; mQtF/ indef det, indef pron (used with [U] ns; esp with negative and interrogative vs or after as, how, so, too Óë²»¿ÉÊıÃû´ÊÁ¬ÓÃ, ÓÈÓë·ñ¶¨Ê½ºÍÒÉÎÊÊ½¶¯´ÊÁ¬ÓÃ»òÓÃì¶as¡¢ how¡¢ so¡¢ tooÖ®áá)  1 a large amount or quantity (of sth) ¶àµÄ; ´óÁ¿µÄ. much
Notice the difference between little/few and a little/a few. ×¢Òâlittle/fewºÍa little/a fewÕâÁ½×é´ÊµÄÇø±ğ. If we say, `I have little money and few interests', we sound disappointed and negative. ÈôËµ: £àI have little money and few interests£¨ÎÒÃ»ÓĞÊ²÷áÇ®, Ò²Ã»ÓĞÊ²÷á°®ºÃ£©£§, ÑÔÓÌâêÈ»ÈôÊ§, º¬·ñ¶¨Òå. If we say, `I have a little money and a few interests', we sound more positive. ÈôËµ: £àI have a little money and a few interests£¨ÎÒÓĞµã¶ùÇ®, Ò²ÓĞĞ©°®ºÃ£©£§, Ôòº¬¿Ï¶¨Òå. Compare ÊÔ±È½Ï: He's lived here a long time but has few friends £¨ËûÔÚÕâ¶ù×¡ÁËºÜ³¤Ê±¼ä, ¿ÉÊÇÃ»Ê²÷áÅóÓÑ£©ºÍHe's lived here a short time but already has a few friends £¨ËûÔÚÕâ¶ù×¡µÃÊ±¼äºÜ¶Ì, ¿ÉÊÇÒÑ¾­ÓĞĞ©ÅóÓÑÁË£©. 2A lot of can also be used in questions *a lot of Òà¿ÉÓÃì¶ÒÉÎÊ¾ä: Have we got a lot of time/cards left? £¨ÎÒÃÇÊ£ÏÂµÄÊ±¼ä[¿¨Æ¬]¶à²»¶à?£© It suggests that the speaker knows that there is/are some left and wants to know whether the amount/number is big or small. Õâ¾ä»°µÄº¬ÒåÊÇ·¢ÎÊÕßÖªµÀÓĞĞ©Ê£Óà, »¹ÏëÖªµÀÊ£ÓàµÄÊıÁ¿ÊÇ¶àÊÇÉÙ. 3The comparative and superlative forms of much, many, and a lot of are more and (the) most. *much¡¢ many¡¢ a lot ofµÄ±È½Ï¼¶ÊÇmore, ×î¸ß¼¶ÊÇ(the) most. For little the comparative and superlative forms are less and (the) least and for few they are fewer and (the) fewest. *littleµÄ±È½Ï¼¶ÊÇless, ×î¸ß¼¶ÊÇ(the) least; fewµÄ±È½Ï¼¶ÊÇfewer, ×î¸ß¼¶ÊÇ(the) fewest.
much
/ mQtF; mQtF/ adv to a great extent or degree ºÜ; ·Ç³£; ÔÚºÜ´ó³Ì¶ÈÉÏ.  1 (often used with negative vs ³£Óë·ñ¶¨Ê½¶¯´ÊÁ¬ÓÃ): She didn't enjoy the film (very) much. musical chairs   
1 game in which players go round a row of chairs (one fewer than the number of players) until the music stops, when the one who finds no chair to sit on has to leave the game ÇÀÒÎ×ÓÓÎÏ·£¨²Î¼ÓÕßËæÀÖÉùÈÆÒÎ×ÓĞĞ×ß, ÒÎÊı±ÈÈËÊıÉÙÒ», ÒôÀÖÍ£Ê±ÇÀÒÎ¶ø×ø, ÎŞ×ùÕßÌÔÌ­£©.  2 (fig often derog ±ÈÓ÷, ³£×÷±áÒå) situation in which people frequently take turns to have sth, esp a job ¿¿ÂÖÁ÷²Å»ñµÃÄ³ÊÂÎïµÄÇéĞÎ£¨ÓÈÖ¸»ñµÃ¹¤×÷£©: He had come out on top in the game of musical chairs by which senior posts seemed to be filled. ÒÑ¾­ÂÖµ½Ëû»ñµÃ¸ß¼¶Ö°Î»ÁË, ÕâÖÖÖ°Î»ËÆºõÊÇÒªÂÖºòµÄ.

must
/ mEst; mEst, strong form Ç¿¶ÁÊ½ mQst; mQst/ modal v (neg ·ñ¶¨Ê½ must not, contracted form ËõÔ¼Ê½ mustn't / 5mQsnt; `mQsnt/)  1 (a) (indicating obligation ±íÊ¾±ØÒª): I must go to the bank to get some money. ÎÒÃÇ²»ÄÜ³Ùµ½, ÊÇ°É? * `Must you go so soon?' `Yes, I must.' £àÄãÒ»¶¨µÃÕâ÷áÔç¾Í×ßÂğ?£§£àÊÇµÄ, ±ØĞëÕâ÷áÔç.£§ =>Usage 1 ¼ûËù¸½ÓÃ·¨µÚ1Ïî. ÎÒµÃÈ°Äã²»ÒªÔÙ×öÄÇÖÖÊÂÇéÁË. =>Usage 2 ¼ûËù¸½ÓÃ·¨µÚ2Ïî.  2 (drawing a logical conclusion ×ö³öÂß¼­ÍÆ¶Ï): You must be hungry after your long walk. Äã×ßÁËÄÇ÷á³¤µÄÂ·, Ò»¶¨¶öÁË°É. * She must be having a lot of problems with the language. ËıÔÚÓïÑÔÉÏÒ»¶¨ÓĞºÜ¶àÀ§ÄÑ. * You must be Mr Smith  I was told to expect you. Äã×¼ÊÇÊ·ÃÜË¹ÏÈÉú°É--ÎÒÊÇ·Ô¸ÀÀ´½ÓÄãµÄ. * They must be twins. ËûÃÇÒ»¶¨ÊÇË«°ûÌ¥. * He must have known (ie Surely he knew) what she wanted. Ëûµ±Ê±¿Ï¶¨ÖªµÀËıĞèÒªÊ²÷á. * We must have read the same report. must

must
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 OBLIGATION (must, need1,2, have to, ought to, should1) ÒåÎñ»òÔğÈÎ£¨must¡¢ need1, 2¡¢ have to¡¢ ought to¡¢ should£© (a) Must is used to show that the speaker orders or expects something to be done *mustÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾Ëµ»°ÕßÃüÁî»òÆÚ´ı×ö³ÉÄ³ÊÂ: The children must be back by 4 o'clock. º¢×Ó±ØĞë4µãÖÓÒÔÇ°»ØÀ´. *  I must go now, ie I feel obliged to go. ÎÒÏÖÔÚµÃ×ßÁË, ¼´ÎÒ¾õµÃÓĞ´Ë±ØÒª. Need to (informal have to) is used when somebody else is giving orders or controlling events *need to£¨Í¨Ë×ÓÃ´ÊÎªhave to£©ÓÃì¶ËûÈË·¢³öÖ¸Áî»ò²Ù×İµÄÇé¿öÏÂ: You need to/have to pass a special exam to get into the school. ÄãÒªÉÏÄÇËùÑ§Ğ£µÃÍ¨¹ıÒ»´ÎÌØ±ğµÄ¿¼ÊÔ. *  I have to go now, ie something (or somebody else) requires it. ÎÒÏÖÔÚµÃ×ßÁË, ¼´Ä³ÊÂ»òÄ³ÈËÒªÇóÎÒÈç´Ë. Ought to and should indicate that the speaker is giving an order, but suggest that he or she is not sure it will be obeyed *ought toºÍshould±íÊ¾Ëµ»°Õß·¢³öÖ¸Áî, µ«°µº¬¶Ô·½ÊÇ·ñÌı´Ó²¢ÎŞ°ÑÎÕÖ®Òâ: She really ought to/should be leaving now. ËıÏÖÔÚ¿ÉÕæ¸Ã×ßÁË. *  You ought to/should apologize (though I'm not sure you will). ÄãÓ¦¸ÃµÀÇ¸£¨ËäÈ»ÎÒ²»ÖªµÀÄãÊÇ·ñÕâÑù×ö£©. (b) Mustn't (and oughtn't to, shouldn't) are used when the speaker wants somebody not to do something*mustn't£¨ºÍoughtn't to¡¢ shouldn't£©ÓÃì¶Ëµ»°ÕßÒªÄ³ÈË²»×öÄ³ÊÂ: You mustn't leave the gate open. Äã²»Òª³¨Öø´óÃÅ. *  You oughtn't to/shouldn't neglect the garden. Äã²»Òª²»¹Ü»¨Ô°. Needn't and don't have to mean that there is a lack of obligation to do something *needn' tºÍdon' t have toÒâÖ¸Ã»ÓĞ×öÄ³ÊÂµÄÒåÎñ»òÔğÈÎ: You needn't/don't have to arrive early. (Cf You mustn't arrive early.) Äã²»±ØÔçÀ´. £¨²Î¿´: Äã²»ÒªÔçÀ´.£© (c) In indirect commands, had to replaces must ÔÚ¼ä½ÓÖ¸ÁîÖĞÓÃhad toÈ¡´úmust: Mother said that the children had to be back by 4 o'clock. (Cf Mary said he ought to/should apologize.) Ä¸Ç×ËµÁËº¢×Ó4µãÒÔÇ°±ØĞë»ØÀ´. £¨²Î¿´: ÂêÀöËµËûÓ¦¸ÃµÀÇ¸.£©  2 ADVICE (must, have got to, ought to, should1) È°¸æ»ò½¨Òé£¨must¡¢ have got to¡¢ ought to¡¢ should1£© (a) Must (informal have got to) is used to advise or recommend *must£¨Í¨Ë×ÓÃ´ÊÎªhave got to£©ÓÃÒÔÌá³öÈ°¸æ»ò½¨Òé: You simply must see that film. Äã¿ÉµÃ¿´¿´Õâ²¿µçÓ°. *  You've got to take life more seriously. Äã¶Ô´ıÉú»îÒªÑÏËàÒ»Ğ©. Ought to and should suggest that the speaker is less confident the advice will be taken *ought toºÍshouldº¬ÓĞËµ»°Õß¶ÔÈ°¸æÖ®ÊÇ·ñ½ÓÊÜ¸üÎŞ°ÑÎÕÖ®Òâ: You really ought to/should do something about that cough! Äã¿ÈËÔÄÇ÷áÀ÷º¦, ÕæµÃÖÎÒ»ÖÎÁË! (b) To advise somebody not to do something, mustn't, oughtn't to and shouldn't are used È°Ä³ÈË²»×öÄ³ÊÂÊ±, ÓÃmustn't¡¢ oughtn't to¡¢ shouldn't: You mustn't/oughtn't to/shouldn't miss this opportunity. Äã²»¿É[²»¸Ã/²»Ó¦]´í¹ıÕâ¸ö»ú»á. (c) In indirect speech, the same rules apply as for OBLIGATION. ÔÚ¼ä½ÓÒıÓÃÓïÖĞ,Ç°ÊöÓÃì¶±íÊ¾ÒåÎñ»òÔğÈÎµÄ¹æÔòÒ²ÊÊÓÃì¶´Ë.  3 DRAWING CONCLUSIONS (must, have to, ought to, should1) ×÷½áÂÛ£¨must¡¢ have to¡¢ ought to¡¢ should1£© (a) Must and have to (informal) are used when drawing a conclusion about which there is no doubt *mustºÍhave to£¨½ÏÍ¨Ë×£©ÓÃì¶ºÁÎŞ»³ÒÉµÄ½áÂÛ: He must be/has to be the wanted man: he's exactly like his picture. ËûÒ»¶¨ÊÇÊÜÍ¨¼©µÄÄÇ¸öÄĞ×Ó: ËûºÍÕÕÆ¬ÉÏµÄÈËÒ»Ä£Ò»Ñù. Ought to and should indicate that the speaker is being more tentative *ought toºÍshould±íÊ¾Ëµ»°ÕßÓĞ½Ï´óµÄÊÔÌ½ĞÔ: He ought to/should be here in time  he started early enough. Ëû¸Ã[Ó¦]°´Ê±µ½ÕâÀï--Ëû³ö·¢µÃ¹»ÔçµÄ. (b) To show that a conclusion cannot be drawn, can't is used ±íÊ¾ÎŞ·¨¶¨ÂÛÔòÓÃcan't: He can't be the wanted man. Ëû²»»áÊÇÄÇ¸ö±»Í¨¼©µÄÄĞ×Ó. *  He can't (surely) get here in time. Ëû£¨¿Ï¶¨£©²»ÄÜ¼°Ê±¸Ïµ½ÕâÀï. (c) Must have, ought to have and should have are used to draw a conclusion from some past event *must have¡¢ ought to have¡¢ should haveÓÃÒÔ¶ÔÄ³¼ş¹ıÈ¥µÄÊÂÇé×÷½áÂÛ: She must have received the parcel: I sent it by registered post. ËıÒ»¶¨ÒÑ¾­ÊÕµ½°ü¹üÁË, ÎÒÊÇÓÃ¹ÒºÅ¼ÄµÄ.

mute

mute 
v [Tn esp passive ÓÈÓÃì¶±»¶¯ÓïÌ¬] make the sound of (esp a musical instrument) quieter or softer, esp with a mute Ê¹ÉùÒô£¨ÓÈÖ¸ÀÖÆ÷Éù£©¼õÈõ, ÈáºÍ£¨ÓÈÖ¸ÓÃÈõÒôÆ÷£©: The strings are muted throughout the closing bars of the symphony. ¸Ã½»ÏìÇú½áÊø²¿·Ö¸÷½ÚÖĞµÄÏÒÀÖÈ«ÎªÈõ»¯Òô. muted adj  1 (of sounds) quiet and often indistinct £¨Ö¸ÉùÒô£©Èõ»¯µÄ, £¨³£Ö¸£©Î¢Èõ²»ÇåµÄ: They spoke in muted voices. ËûÃÇÇáÉùËµ»°.  2 not openly or vigorously expressed ·Ç¹«¿ª»ò·ÇÇ¿ÁÒ±í´ïµÄ; °µÖĞµÄ: muted excitement ÄÚĞÄµÄ¼¤¶¯ * muted criticism ÎÂºÍµÄÅúÆÀ.  3 (of musical instruments) fitted with a mute £¨Ö¸ÀÖÆ÷£©×°ÓĞÈõÒôÆ÷µÄ: muted strings ×°ÓĞÈõÒôÆ÷µÄÇÙÏÒ.  4 (of colours) not bright; subdued £¨Ö¸ÑÕÉ«£©²»Ò«ÑÛµÄ, ÈáºÍµÄ: muted greens and blues ¸÷ÖÖÈáºÍµÄÂÌÉ«ºÍÀ¶É«.

mutilate
